text:
Sombero back, vows to testify on BI bribery scandal By Rudy Santos and Evelyn Macairan (The Philippine Star)   12:00am Retired police offi cer Wally Sombero raises his hat after he was met by immigration offi cials and members of the National Bureau of Investigation upon arrival at the NAIA. RUDY SANTOS 
MANILA, Philippines - Retired police officer Wenceslao “Wally” Sombero has insisted he is no briber, but a whistle-blower of extortion activities in the Bureau of Immigration (BI). 
He also denied going into hiding, claiming he had permission to leave the country from Justice Secretary Vitaliano Aguirre II. 
But Aguirre firmly denied this. 
Arriving at 8:55 a.m. yesterday at the Ninoy Aquino International Airport from Canada, the alleged middleman of Chinese gaming mogul Jack Lam said he had no plans of escaping. 
Sombero is being accused of bribing immigration officials on Lam’s behalf to release the latter’s arrested illegal Chinese workers. 
“Nagpapalamig lang at wala akong balak tumakas (Just wanted to cool off and I don’t have plans of escaping),” he said.   
Sombero was met yesterday at the airport by Immigration Terminal 2 head supervisor Dennis Robles, Port Operations Division assistant head Fidel Mendoza and agents of the National Bureau of Investigation (NBI). 
Traveling alone from Vancouver, Canada, Sombero took Philippine Airlines flight PR 119 and was in seat 2D of business class. 
An airline staff, who asked not to be identified, said Sombero seemed “nervous,” going to the lavatory several times when the plane was about to land. 
Sombero said he left the country last Jan. 17 with Aguirre’s permission and made a stopover in Taiwan before flying to Vancouver. 
But according to Aguirre, he did not issue an Allowed Departure Order (ADO) to Sombero when he asked to leave the country. 
Sombero said last Jan. 16, the day before he left, he wrote the justice secretary a letter stating his intention to leave. 
“Yes, he wrote to me, but… I did not issue an allowed departure order… I did not allow it,” Aguirre stressed, noting that Sombero was in the list of the Immigration Lookout Bulletin Order (ILBO) since Dec. 16 last year because of the bribery/extortion scandal at the immigration bureau. 
The DOJ chief said it was the job of the immigration officer to stop Sombero from leaving the country, since the latter was a subject of an ILBO. 
“In the case of Sombero, he had no ADO, so the immigration officer should have prevented him. It is no longer the fault of the DOJ (Department of Justice) secretary,” Aguirre pointed out. 
Last Monday, Aguirre issued an “extremely urgent” memorandum for BI Commissioner Jaime Morente and NBI director Dante Gierran on the expected arrival of Sombero yesterday at 7:30 a.m. from Vancouver. 
The justice secretary ordered the NBI to give Sombero the necessary protective custody as the agency assists and turns him over to the Blue Ribbon committee of the Senate in time for the next hearing on Feb. 16. 
Sombero was turned over to Senate officials at the airport yesterday. 
He said he had no knowledge to link Aguirre to the immigration bribery scandal. 
Sombero had reportedly left the country for medical reasons and threats on his life over the alleged P50-million bribe to immigration officials from Lam. 
Sombero was set to return to the Philippines from Canada last Feb. 6, in time for the Senate’s third hearing on the case, but was stopped by airport authorities in Canada because he exhibited palpitations and shortness of breath when he was about to board a plane to Manila. 
Canadian authorities reportedly asked Sombero to see a cardiologist before they give him clearance to rebook his flight. 
Sombero said he wants to appear before the Senate committee “to personally assert the fact that it was a consummated extortion case, rather than a mere perception of bribery.” – With Paolo Romero, Marvin Sy
